report_title: e-Discovery Software Publishing in the US
executive_summary: Engineers in the e-Discovery Software Publishing industry are essential for legal firms and corporations to produce evidence from electronically stored information (ESI). This software aggregates data from e-mails, text documents, databases, audio and video files, social media and websites. Increasing regulations regarding the retention, modification and deletion of ESI have prompted many companies to seek e-discovery software to assure legal compliance. Simultaneously, many companies use e-discovery software to handle internal disputes and information leakage. An explosion in the volume of data sent over the internet has also bolstered interest in e-discovery products. Both factors helped developers prosper for much of the period, despite a decline in 2020 due to COVID-19. Overall, revenue is estimated to increase at an annualized rate of 5.7% to $2.9 billion over the five years to 2023, including a 5.9% increase in 2023. Profit has also been strong in recent years, reaching 18.9% in 2023 and encouraging new companies to enter the ring and expand their workforces.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Online Business Expansion Pushed E-Discovery Into the Spotlight
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The rise of electronic business communication, especially mobile and cloud services, has led to an increase in demand for e-discovery software. Social media has also become a significant source of electronic data, which can be used as evidence in court. The task of identifying, collecting, and producing electronic evidence relevant to litigation is burdensome, but e-discovery software remains the most efficient solution.

As a result, the e-Discovery Software Publishing industry has experienced significant sales growth and will continue to do so. E-discovery software was initially used by legal firms, but now large banks, financial and insurance firms, and multinational corporations are implementing information governance (IG) to manage and organize their electronic data.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Regulatory Impacts Guide the Development of E-Discovery Software
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: E-discovery exploded in popularity in the early 2000s after the US Supreme Court revised the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure (FRCP) to include digital evidence explicitly. In 2006, the FRCP was amended to cover e-discovery procedures, focusing on protecting instant messaging and e-mail. In April 2015, the Supreme Court adopted several key amendments to the FRCP, which increase the scope of e-discovery and the degree to which sanctions are imposed.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Data Dependence Will Drive More E-Discovery Software Use
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: More frequent digital technology use among businesses will continue to drive exponential greater use of e-discovery software to manage and track it all. Software vendors will employ litigation and supporting professionals to help sell e-discovery products, advising on software that has the high processing speed, can display items in native formats and helps reviewers move from one document to another, all while collecting and compiling necessary information.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Calls for Government Transparency Will Push the Adoption of E-Discovery Packages
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Government agencies are expected to increase demand for technology to manage obsolete proprietary data safely and transparently. A 2015 Deloitte survey found that over half of government respondents would be unable to demonstrate the accuracy, accessibility, completeness and trustworthiness of their electronic information if challenged in a lawsuit. As a result, government agencies will purchase e-Discovery software to ensure compliance with federal transparency mandates as calls for government openness grow louder.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Rising Costs for Cloud-Hosted Software May Decrease Profit in the Years to Come
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Profit may decline slightly, though still remaining extremely high due to pricing pressure caused by cloud data management managed by software providers. Vendors will offer simpler pricing models and more one-stop shop services instead of charging a-la-carte or focusing on the up-front cost. More businesses are expected begin developing e-discovery software as the number of digital-focused lawsuits increases.

industry_definition: Electronic discovery (e-discovery) refers to any process through which electronic data is searched, located and secured for use as evidence in a court of law. In the United States, this industry includes operators that develop software-based e-discovery platforms. In addition to software development, some operators provide technical support and services.

mixed_impact_factors: Medium - Increasing Barriers To Entry Level

key_trends: The proliferation of mobile devices and internet use has propelled industry growth
The Supreme Court adopted several key amendments of the FRCP
Strong growth and potential in the industry have encouraged new entrants
The primary driver of performance will continue to be digital technology

market_segmentation.segment_description: This segment includes several large corporations like financial institutions, insurance companies and auditors use e-discovery software.
The legal representative for a company or individual will recommend or refer the client to an e-discovery software publishing and consulting firm.
Rising calls for transparency and use of record management in the public sector generate a need for e-discovery and digital investigations software to present information to the public.

products_and_services.product_description: Clients Link New Software to Existing Frameworks

tier_1_suppliers: Operating Systems & Productivity Software Publishing in the US
Telecommunication Networking Equipment Manufacturing in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Database, Storage & Backup Software Publishing in the US
Electronic & Computer Repair Services in the US
tier_2_buyers: Finance and Insurance in the US
Healthcare and Social Assistance in the US
Human Resources & Benefits Administration in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Government regulations determine demand primarily through their imposition on business and bureaucratic activities.
The amount of litigation determines demand as litigators often use industry products to search for evidence.
At any given time, a company's budget plays a role in determining demand for e-discovery software.
As digital storage capabilities increase, demand for services that help companies manage their digital archives will increase.

business_locations.location_description: Silicon Valley Holds One-Quarter of the Industry
MORE PEOPLE IN THE MID-ATLANTIC REGION LEADS TO MORE BUSINESS LOCATIONS

regulations_points.regulation_description: Since 2006, federal rules regarding documents for inclusion during a legal hold procedure have included electronically stored information (ESI).
US copyright laws protect copyright owners from the unauthorized reproduction, adaptation, performance, display or distribution of copyright-protected works.
In 1988, the United States became a signatory of the Berne Convention for the Protection of Literary and Artistic Works, which is administered by the World Intellectual Property Organization.
E-discovery providers are also required to follow regulations enacted to slow the spread of the pandemic.

barriers_points.barrier_description: While there are few formal legal restrictions to starting an e-discovery software company, gaining widespread legal acceptance is its own hurdle.
Start-up costs are relatively moderate, but extremely high compared with the software space. The complexity and reliability demands of inputs to legal trials are immense.
Competition for skilled employees also serves as a barrier to entry for this industry.

basis_points.basis_title: Software efficiency, accuracy, automation and usability
basis_points.basis_description: E-Discovery Software publishers compete on software efficiency, accuracy, automation and usability.
Because speed in producing actionable results appeals to legal clients, e-discovery software programmers compete to build applications that parse, sort and display more data faster.

basis_points.basis_title: Customer service, support and product offerings
basis_points.basis_description: Other areas of competition include customer service and support and the breadth and depth of product offerings as required by downstream markets.

concentration_points.concentration_description: E-DISCOVERY SOFTWARE LACKS A CLEAR MARKET LEADER. The absence of a dominant player makes it easier for new entrants to compete and succeed.
E-discovery is becoming more competitive as demand for the software category broadens, attracting even more interest from newcomers.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Profit spread widens as legal clients consistently demand the best software
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The drag from underperforming e-discovery software publishing companies has depressed profit to be generally lower than profit in other software industries, though still high at 19.6% in 2023.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Wages Rise With Developer Shortage and Education Requirements
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: All software companies spend extensively on wages to pay skilled developers; e-discovery software production is no exception, spending 33.0% of revenue in 2023.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchases Decline as Physical Software Use Wanes Further
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: While some software and systems may be delivered as hardware and USBs in packages bearing branded marketing, physical packaging is highly unusual.
Depreciation accounts for 1.3% of industry revenue in 2023.
Marketing costs are expected to account for 4.8% of industry revenue in 2023.
Rent costs for this industry are anticipated to account for 2.2% of expenses in 2023.
Utility costs are expected to account for 0.2% of industry revenue in 2023.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Other Outflows are Inconsistent and Dominated by Research Costs
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: R&D and other costs for e-discovery software publishers are significant and near 36.1% of revenue in 2023.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The e-Discovery Software Publishing industry has a low level of capital intensity. On average, the industry is expected to spend $0.04 for every $1.00 spent on wages in 2023.
The technical requirements of software development and implementation carry moderate costs in the form of computers and software.
The e-Discovery Software Publishing industry has experienced little technological disruption.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Software businesses are rapidly switching to the subscription model for their software, forcing users to pay monthly or yearly instead of all at once.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Slower corporate upgrades during COVID-19 lead to a spike in volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: As corporate profit declines, companies may hold off on purchases of updated software, instead planning on purchasing it as profit increases.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: As a technology-based industry, research and development activities are high for e-discovery service providers and software developers.

FAQs.question: How has the shift towards conducting business online affected demand for your services?
FAQs.answer: The shift online has opened a new distribution channel for industry companies; the cloud. Through the cloud, customers can pay for services on a subscription basis and receive regular software updates. The COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic has increased the importance of conducting business online, driving companies to further invest in cloud computing.

FAQs.question: Has technology (i.e. data storage and analytics) affected the type of customers you sell to?
FAQs.answer: Compared to costly one-time purchases, cloud-based solutions are marketable to a wider range of businesses, especially small, as these subscription options enable customers to pay less upfront and develop stronger long-term relationships with developers.

FAQs.question: Is your company strategically located in a region that acts to your benefit?
FAQs.answer: To attract the best talent, companies should be aware of the Silicon Valley area of California, Seattle, New York City and Boston as major tech hubs.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to rising wages in recent years?
FAQs.answer: The industry as a whole has been exposed to rising wages over the past five years as demand for employees is extremely competitive. This sector encompasses some of the largest and cash-ready corporations, including Microsoft, IBM and Oracle, who all push wages up. However, increased unemployment due to the coronavirus pandemic has temporarily relieved the burden of rising wages, although they are expected to rebound over the five years to 2026.

FAQs.question: Has your company prepared adequately to address the increased security risks posed by digital data storage?
FAQs.answer: The cyberattacks on Equifax and web hosting companies, which have temporarily shut down Twitter and Spotify, are among a number of high-profile cyberattacks in recent years. Developers of internet-hosted (cloud) software must ensure that customers' data, designs and technology are protected. The increased usage of internet-hosted software during the coronavirus pandemic has increased the urgency of securing customers' data.

FAQs.question: Has your company been able to keep current with changing digital interfaces?
FAQs.answer: It is vital for software developers, especially smaller companies, to be aware of changing consumer preferences. However, industry services are marketed to corporations, not the consumer. As a result, changing digital interfaces do not matter as much. Nevertheless, the coronavirus pandemic has increased the percentage of business conducted online, increasing the importance of keeping abreast of changing in business-to-business digital interfaces.

FAQs.question: Do you work with trade associations or other interest groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: On a state and local level, there are a number of groups that are looking to promote software and technology jobs in their area.

FAQs.question: Have any recent regulatory changes significantly affected your operations?
FAQs.answer: Regulation plays a small role in the industry; given the highly fragmented nature of the industry, antitrust litigators generally do not scrutinize industry companies. However, companies in this industry must abide by social and electronic company regulations.

FAQs.question: Do you have any big projects that require capital financing on the horizon?
FAQs.answer: Generally speaking, barriers to entry are moderate in this industry, though new entrants will be challenged to find and fund the right employees, often the bedrock of any successful company. As the overall economy recovers from the COVID-19 pandemic, companies are likely to increase hiring, intensifying competition for skilled employees.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors?
FAQs.answer: Profit margins remain high in this industry. The software industry generally has high profit margins as distribution and overhead costs remain low compared to revenue. However, profit margins declined over the past five years due to rising wage costs, along with the economic fallout of the coronavirus pandemic in 2020.

FAQs.question: Do you regularly use automation in your services? What proportion of automation do use in the process?
FAQs.answer: For e-discovery software and services, automation is the name of the game. The less manual labor required to run an industry operator's software, the more attractive it will be to potential clients. The rollout of 5G wireless networks is expected to increase the ability of companies in this industry to automate their operations.

FAQs.question: How do you ensure your technology is consistently up to date? How have you adjusted your programs' functionality?
FAQs.answer: E-discovery software often includes features that "read" data from diverse sources, including text, audio and images. As native file formats change, e-discovery developers will need to adjust their programs' functionality accordingly.

FAQs.question: Do you employ a range of workers that have technical expertise and customer skills? How do you go about recruiting employees?
FAQs.answer: Many of the larger operators that provide e-discovery software shore up their sales pitch with the provision of after-sales service, troubleshooting and (in some cases) hands-on training for new clients. The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the essential nature of robust virtual and phone-based after-sales service, as social distancing restrictions make in-person support less feasible.

FAQs.question: How much do you rely on external investment? If investment funding should falter, how will you shore up revenue?
FAQs.answer: As the prime rate increases, borrowing money, which fuels business expansions, becomes more expensive. As a result, companies may hold off on expansion plans until a later date and growth rates may be limited. Interest rates were brought down to near-zero levels in 2020 in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, making investment more affordable for companies in this industry. However, the prime rate will likely increase over the five years to 2026, as an economic recovery spurs the Federal Reserve to safeguard against excessive inflation.

FAQs.question: What proportion of your revenue comes from law firms? How can you boost demand from this segment?
FAQs.answer: Law firms represent a significant market for industry operators, as corporate attorneys demand e-discovery software and services for use in business.

FAQs.question: How do rising online purchases affect demand for your company? Are you working on expanding your product offering to cater to online advertisers?
FAQs.answer: An increase in the percentage of services conducted online will increase the amount of information that can potentially be discovered online and, consequently, increase revenue for operators. The percentage of services conducted online increased significantly in 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic, a trend that is expected to remain in place even as the pandemic subsides, potentially increasing long-term revenue opportunities for industry operators.
